sentences: Cameron Jibril Thomaz (born September 8, 1987), better known by his stage name Wiz Khalifa, is an American rapper, singer, and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: He released his debut album, Show and Prove, in 2006, and signed to Warner Bros. Records in 2007.
section: N/A

sentences: His Eurodance-influenced single "Say Yeah" received urban radio airplay, charting on the Rhythmic Top 40 and Hot Rap Tracks charts in 2008, becoming his first minor hit.
section: N/A

sentences: Thomaz parted with Warner Bros. and released his second album, Deal or No Deal, in November 2009.
section: N/A

sentences: He released the mixtape Kush and Orange Juice as a free download in April 2010; he then signed with Atlantic Records.
section: N/A

sentences: Thomaz then adopted a more radio-friendly, pop-oriented approach with his debut single for Atlantic, "Black and Yellow".
section: N/A

sentences: The song, a tribute to his hometown of Pittsburgh, debuted at number 100 and eventually peaked at number 1 on the Billboard Hot 100.
section: N/A

sentences: The song became the lead single for his third album Rolling Papers, which was released in March 2011, and also had the Top 40 singles "Roll Up" and "No Sleep".
section: N/A

sentences: The album's success was followed up with O.N.I.F.C. in December 2012, which was backed by the singles "Work Hard, Play Hard" and "Remember You" (featuring the Weeknd).
section: N/A

sentences: Wiz released his fifth album Blacc Hollywood in August 2014, backed by the lead single "We Dem Boyz".
section: N/A

sentences: In March 2015, he released "See You Again" (featuring Charlie Puth) for the soundtrack of the film Furious 7 and the song peaked at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 for 12 non-consecutive weeks.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Khalifa was born Cameron Jibril Thomaz on September 8, 1987 in Minot, North Dakota to parents serving in the military.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His parents divorced when Khalifa was about three years old.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is a military brat with his parents' military service causing him to move regularly.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Khalifa lived in Germany, the United Kingdom, and Japan before settling in Pittsburgh with his mother in around 1996 where he attended Taylor Allderdice High School.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Soon after moving to Pittsburgh, Khalifa began to write and perform his own lyrics before he was a teenager.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His stage name is derived from Khalifa, an Arabic word meaning "successor", and wisdom, which was shortened to Wiz when Khalifa was a young boy.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Khalifa stated to Spinner.com that the name also came from being called "young Wiz 'cause I was good at everything I did, and my granddad is Muslim, so he gave me that name; he felt like that's what I was doing with my music."
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He got a tattoo of his stage name on his 17th birthday.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: By the age of 15 he was regularly recording his music in a studio called I.D. Labs.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The management of the studio was so impressed by his lyrics that they allowed Khalifa to record for free.
section: == Early life ==

== Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Rostrum Records president Benjy Grinberg first heard about Wiz Khalifa in 2004 when the rapper's contribution to a mixtape of various new Pittsburgh artists attracted his interest.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: When Grinberg finally met the 16-year-old artist, he immediately decided he wanted to work with him, later telling HitQuarters: "Even though he wasn't all the way developed you could just tell that he was a diamond in the rough, and that with some polishing, guidance and backing he could become something special."
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa signed to the label shortly after and began a seven-year period of artist development.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa released his first mixtape, Prince of the City: Welcome to Pistolvania, in 2005.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: The mixtape paved the way for his first full-length album entitled Show and Prove in 2006.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa was declared an "artist to watch" that year in Rolling Stone magazine.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: In 2007, Khalifa signed to Warner Bros. Records and released two mixtapes through Rostrum Records: Grow Season, hosted by DJ Green Lantern and released on July 4, 2007, and Prince of the City 2, released on November 20, 2007.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: His debut Warner Bros. single "Say Yeah" reached number 25 on the Billboard Rhythmic Top 40 music chart and number 20 on Billboard's Hot Rap Tracks.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: The song samples "Better Off Alone" by Alice Deejay.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa's vocals from "Say Yeah" appear near the end of Pittsburgh mashup producer Girl Talk's 2008 album, Feed the Animals, over music from Underworld's "Born Slippy", Usher's "Love in This Club", and the Cure's "In Between Days".
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa appeared with The Game, David Banner and Play-n-Skillz at U92's Summer Jam at the USANA Amphitheatre in West Valley City, Utah on August 2, 2008.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa released the mixtapes Star Power in September 2008, and Flight School in April 2009 on Rostrum Records.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa parted ways with Warner Bros. Records in July 2009 after numerous delays in releasing his planned debut album for the label, First Flight.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa stated to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette that, "I learned a lot during my time there and matured as an artist during the process.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: I'm happy to be moving on with all of my material and having the chance to be in control of my next moves".
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa appeared with Girl Talk, Modey Lemon, Donora, Grand Buffet, and Don Caballero at the Amphitheatre at Station Square in Pittsburgh on July 31, 2009, where he announced that his relationship with Warner Bros. was over.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2008: Early mixtapes and Show and Prove ===

sentences: Khalifa introduced a more melodic style on the mixtape, alternating between singing and rapping.

section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: This Is It" by Camp Lo, and  "Best I Ever Had" by Drake.

sentences: Wiz Khalifa was named 2010 "Rookie Of The Year" by "The Source", with alongside Rick Ross, "The Man Of The Year".

sentences: Khalifa released the free mixtape Kush and Orange Juice for download on June 14, 2010.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: Due to Khalifa's devoted grassroots fan base, the mixtape became the No. 1 trending topic on Twitter with the hash tag #kushandorangejuice, and "Kush and Orange Juice download" ranked No. 1 on Google's hot search trends.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: Citing music industry insiders, New York magazine wrote that Khalifa signed with Atlantic Records in April 2010, although the rapper did not confirm it.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: He stated to AllHipHop in June 2010 that he was working on a new album, but was weighing his options and had not yet decided on a label to distribute it.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: Khalifa confirmed to MTV on July 30 that he was signing an Atlantic Records deal.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: Khalifa was featured in a remix and video for the 2010 Rick Ross single "Super High", alongside Curren$y.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: He guested on the mixtape Grey Goose, Head Phones, and Thirsty Women  by St. Louis rapper M.C, and was featured on the track "The Breeze (Cool)" on rapper Wale's August 2010 mixtape More About Nothing.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: Khalifa was named MTV's Hottest Breakthrough MC of 2010, winning with nearly 70,000 votes, and beating out finalists Nicki Minaj, J. Cole, Travis Porter, and Diggy Simmons.

sentences: Khalifa appeared at the Soundset 2010 festival in May 2010 in Minneapolis, Minnesota, alongside Method Man & Redman, Del the Funky Homosapien and Hieroglyphics, Atmosphere, Murs, Cage, and others.

sentences: He performed at the 2010 Rock the Bells festival, along with hip hop veterans Wu-Tang Clan, Snoop Dogg, Lauryn Hill, A Tribe Called Quest, Rakim, KRS-One, Jedi Mind Tricks and Slick Rick.

sentences: Khalifa declined an invitation to tour with rapper Drake and launched his own Waken Baken Tour, a 50-city national tour with rapper Yelawolf.

sentences: His official DJ on the tour was DJ Bonics.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: The tour, scheduled to last from September to November 2010, sold out every venue.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: In November 2010, during his "Waken Baken" tour at East Carolina University, Khalifa was arrested for possession and trafficking of marijuana.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2010: Deal or No Deal and signing with Atlantic Records ===

sentences: He was released the next morning after a $300K bail, and resumed his tour.

section: == Career == | === 2013–present: Blacc Hollywood and Rolling Papers 2 ===

sentences: That same month, Khalifa and Charlie Puth released the song "See You Again", a tribute to Paul Walker, who died during filming for Furious 7.
section: == Career == | === 2013–present: Blacc Hollywood and Rolling Papers 2 ===

sentences: After releasing several "Weedmixes" on SoundCloud, including "Ziplocc" and "Maan!", Wiz took to Twitter to create hype about his new mixtape, 28 Grams, which was due to be released on May 25, 2014.

sentences: However, Wiz was arrested in El Paso, Texas for marijuana possession the day before, and there were fears that the mixtape would be pushed back.
section: == Career == | === 2013–present: Blacc Hollywood and Rolling Papers 2 ===

sentences: After posting a "jail selfie" and hashtagging "FreeTrapWiz" on Twitter, he was released hours later, meaning the mixtape would go ahead with its intended release date.

sentences: However, the album was released on February 5, 2016.

sentences: Khalifa is seeking $1 million in compensation as well as punitive damages and attorney fees.

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Khalifa began dating model Amber Rose in early 2011.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They got engaged on March 1, 2012, and married on July 8, 2013.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They have one son, Sebastian Taylor (born 2013).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On September 24, 2014, it was announced that Rose would be filing for divorce, citing irreconcilable differences.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: As of 2015, Khalifa and Rose have joint custody of their son.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Khalifa is open about his use of cannabis, and he has claimed in many interviews that he spends $10,000 a month on cannabis, and also smokes daily.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: As of early 2014, Khalifa no longer pays for cannabis and is sponsored by The Cookie Company, a medical marijuana dispenser which sells his "Khalifa Kush" (KK) strain, which he partnered with RiverRock Cannabis to create.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Also, in 2016 Khalifa was featured in a cooking show with Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg where weed was the main ingredient.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Khalifa began training in the martial art Brazilian jiu-jitsu in May 2017 with Rigan Machado, an 8th degree red and black belt.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Shortly after, he began training in Muay Thai with former UFC bantamweight title contender Cat Zingano and at the Unbreakable Performance Center in Los Angeles.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On April 24, 2018, Yokkao hosted a private Muay Thai seminar with Thai boxing legend Saenchai for Khalifa at Unbreakable.
section: == Personal life ==
